title: SB 1.18.26 Part 1 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 15-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Similarly, inquiries by Pariksit Maharaj and the answers by Shukadeva Goswami constitute the entire Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the context of the lecture, explaining that it is based on the 26th verse of the 18th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, and draws a parallel between the conversation between Arjuna and Krishna leading to the Bhagavad Gita and the inquiries of Pariksit Maharaj and the answers of Shukadeva Goswami constituting the Srimad Bhagavatam.

segments.key_quote: But what was the real state of consciousness that is very precisely described in this verse?
segments.summary: The speaker reads the translation of the 26th verse, emphasizing its technical description of the state of consciousness of Samika Rishi during meditation.

segments.key_quote: So, the spiritual engagement is possible provided, first of all, we practice controlling, restraining these senses and gradually elevate these senses to the spiritual position, spiritual platform.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the meaning of the verse, explaining how the senses, breath, mind, and intelligence are restrained from material activities in spiritual practice.

segments.key_quote: He was situated in a state apart from the three states of consciousness.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the concept of trance and introduces the three states of consciousness: wakefulness, dream, and unconsciousness, focusing on the wakeful state.

segments.key_quote: These five senses are the gateway for our interaction with the outside world.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the dream state, explaining how the external interaction is stopped and the five senses are shut off.

segments.key_quote: That dream world is a subtle world.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to describe the dream state as a subtle world experienced through the mind, and introduces the unconscious state.

segments.key_quote: But subtle experience is there, that is there in the dream state
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of not remembering all incidents in the wakeful state to explain why we don't always remember our dreams, emphasizing the subtle experience in the dream state.

segments.key_quote: Unconscious state is the state in which you are not aware of the dream world and you are not aware of the external gross world also
segments.summary: The speaker defines the unconscious state and announces that he will continue the discussion of the verse in the next session.
